Graphical abstract A possibility of low temperature catalytic steam gasification of n-C5 asphaltenes mixed in light cyclic oil (LCO) in a fixed bed reactor is tested and presented. Four meta kaolin based catalysts containing one alkali (K or Cs), one alkaline earth (Ca or Ba) metal oxides were characterized and tested. Two of these four catalysts also contained NiO nanoparticles in addition to alkali and alkaline earth metal oxides. Addition of sugar as a porogen to kaolin created meso as well as macroporosity. These mesoporous–macroporous meta kaolin based materials are intended to work mainly as catalysts for steam gasification of the adsorbed asphaltenes. XRD data showed presence of Ni3S2 in the spent catalyst. It was found that low temperature catalytic steam gasification was possible by all four catalysts. However, replacement of Ca by Ba increased H2 production. Also, incorporation of NiO nanoparticles promoted further H2 production during the steam gasification of the adsorbed asphaltenes, leading to CO2 and H2 as major products with less side reactions. Of the two nickel-based catalysts, 3NiO6Cs6Ba seems to be the more promising material, with slightly lower activation energy, and higher production of gases per mole of metal contained in the catalyst. Keywords n-C5 asphaltenes Catalytic steam gasification Kaolin H2 production NiO nanoparticles 1 Introduction Conventional crude oil is the main energy source that meets the global energy demand because of its high quality as well as low production cost. However, conventional oil reserves are now generally agreed to be depleting, as these resources are finite. This has generated more focus on exploitation of unconventional oil reserves [1]. Heavy oil and bitumen reserves are the most unconventional available energy source worldwide and their utilization is predicted to increase in future. One of the main unconventional oil reserves is Alberta’s oil sands, which is comparable to Saudi Arabia in the size of oil reserves, and has been gaining importance as a strategic North American energy supply [2]. There has been a lot of research being carried out in the development of hydrogen generation systems [3]. The most developed technologies for this purpose are reforming and gasification. Gasification usually refers to a thermal process where a carbonaceous feed is transformed to gases like CO, CO2, CH4 and H2 following the reactions presented elsewhere [4]. These reactions depend strongly on temperature, pressure and C to O ratio [4]. The economics of Alberta bitumen coke gasification has been studied in detail and reported elsewhere [5]. Catalytic steam gasification on the other hand refers to similar process occurring in presence of a catalyst. In catalytic steam gasification of coal [6,7] as well as coke [8,9], it has been found that the use of alkaline metal augments the reactivity, and that the effect is higher with higher alkaline metal/C ratio. It has also been reported that the order of catalytic activity of alkaline metals, follows from bottom to top in the periodic table of elements as follows: Cs>Rb>K>Na [4,10]. Pereira et al. have used K–Ca mixture for steam gasification of graphite and chars [11]. They demonstrated that these catalysts had superior resistance to sulphur poisoning as compared to K–Ni catalysts. It may be noted that in majority of the work published the alkali–alkaline earth metals are dispersed in the carbonaceous matrix and subjected to gasification, mostly in a fluidized bed reactor type unit [6]. Bitumen typically comprises more than 50% (w/w) of distillation residua (500°C+). In search of an economically viable upgrading process for bitumen or heavy oil, we have envisaged an alternative processing scheme that may prove viable. This scheme requires the development of a catalyst capable to preferentially adsorb heavy polar hydrocarbons, like asphaltenes, and its ability to perform low temperature catalytic steam gasification. The objective is to separate the unstable heavy polar hydrocarbons (in particular the ones produced during thermal cracking of the residual oil) by adsorbing them onto a solid adsorbent-catalyst. These selectively separated hydrocarbon compounds would then be used to produce H2 via catalytic steam gasification. This mode of gasification is different than conventional gasification and would operate at significantly lower temperatures. In this case, H2 would be produced from the most difficult-to-process asphaltenes rather than natural gas, a cleaner fuel that could better be used for heat and power in order to displace coal in the future. Our recent work on asphaltenes adsorption using nanoparticles [12,13] aluminas [14,15] and modified kaolin [16] showed that incorporation of transition metal oxide nanoparticles on/into kaolin would be advantageous; both in terms of adsorption as well as catalytic activity for steam gasification reactions. This hypothesis was partially confirmed recently [17]. We reported on development of support for asphaltenes adsorption followed by post-adsorption catalytic steam gasification using TGA–MS system. The catalyst used was NiO distributed in mesoporous–macroporous meta kaolin. Evolved gas analysis during TGA–MS experiment indicated H2 production. However, a true catalytic test on a bench scale in a fixed bed reactor unit remained to be performed. An investigation of a fixed bed setup is now presented to confirm the viability of the process. In this work, four catalysts that contained one alkali (K or Cs) and one alkaline earth (Ca or Ba) metal incorporated into mesoporous–macroporous meta kaolin were prepared. Two of these four catalysts contained NiO nanoparticles as well, to investigate the effect of transition metal oxides on product distribution and catalytic activity for catalytic steam gasification of heavy hydrocarbons in a fixed bed reactor unit. The feed used was a mixture of n-C5-asphaltenes mixed with light cyclic oil (LCO) to mimic a real heavy feed. Further details are as follows. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Toluene of HPLC grade from Sigma–Aldrich was used as received. Air, Ar, H2, He, 5% O2 in He and N2, of UHP grade were purchased from Praxair Canada. NiO nanoparticles were obtained from Sigma–Aldrich Canada, Ltd., Oakville, Ontario, Canada. Kaolin was obtained from Merck (Germany). K(CH3COO) and Cs(CH3COO) of 99% purity were obtained from Sigma–Aldrich. Ba(CH3COO)2 and Ca(CH3COO)2 of 99% purity were obtained from Merck (Germany). A hydrocarbon feed consisting of industrial n-C5 asphaltenes fluidized by light cycle oil (30% wt) was used for the screening of catalysts. This sample was provided by Nexen-CNOOC Ltd. 2.2 Elemental and metal analysis S and N Analysis were performed using ANTEK 9000 NS Analyzer. A known amount of asphaltenes was dissolved in toluene and tested for N and S quantification. A calibration curve using six standards was made containing 100–900ppm of N and 1000–10,000ppm of S and used for this purpose. Metal analysis in asphaltenes was performed by Thermo Electron ICP Spectrometer IRIS Intrepid II. Samples for metal analysis were prepared by mixing a known amount of sample in conc. HNO3 and H3PO4 and then digesting it in MARS microwave digestion system (Table 1 ). 2.3 Adsorbents/catalyst preparation Mesoporous–macroporous adsorbents/catalyst supports were prepared by using kaolin as the solid support. The formula of the kaolin used is H2Al2Si2O6·xH2O showing that Si/Al=1. In the kaolin used (as would be shown in following Section 3.2), there are traces of KAl3Si3O11 found as impurity, which is very stable to thermal and hydrothermal treatments. A known amount of kaolin was mixed with an aqueous solution containing known amounts K(CH3COO) or Cs(CH3COO) and Ca(CH3COO)2 or Ba(CH3COO)2. K(CH3COO) was mixed with Ca(CH3COO)2 salt and Cs (CH3COO) with Ba(CH3COO)2 salt. These metal acetates were used as binding agents to render kaolin more basic in nature. Sucrose was then added to kaolin in known amounts to act as a porogen. In a couple of cases, NiO nanopowder was added to the mixture. Extrudates were drawn from the resulting dough, using an in-house built machine, and dried overnight at room temperature. Dried extrudates of kaolin were then calcined at 650°C under air for 8h in a muffle furnace to form a mesoporous–macroporous material. The extrudated catalysts were broken into small pieces. The extrudates were 1.50mm in diameter and 15–20mm in length. Kaolin transformed into meta kaolin because of calcination in air beyond 600°C [17]. The composition by wt.% of the catalysts used in this study is listed in Table 2 . 2.4 Thermogravimetric analysis (TG-DTA) About 30mg of sample in extrudate form was heated in a simultaneous thermal analyzer Q600 (TA Instruments, USA) from ambient temperatures to the required temperature. The heating rate was kept at 10°C/min. The system was purged with air flowing at 100cc/min until the end of the experiment. 2.5 X-ray powder diffraction The X-ray analysis of the prepared materials was performed using a Rigaku ULTIMA III X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation as the X-ray source. For each sample, the scan was done in the range of 5–90 2θ° using a 0.02° step and a counting time of 1.0°/s to obtain the full diffractogram. The domain crystal sizes were measured using the Scherrer equation, as implemented in the commercial software JADE [18] (provided with the diffractometer) by fitting the experimental profile to a pseudo-Voigt profile function, and then, calculating the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the peak. The presented crystalline domain size data corresponds to the most intense peak in the 2θ signal: for NiO the maximum around 43.3°, which belongs to the plane (20 0) and for Ni3S2 the maximum around 31.1°, which belongs to the plane (110). 2.6 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR)/oxidation (TPO) Temperature programmed reduction or oxidation of Ni-based catalysts was carried out in Chembet 3000 (Quantachrome Instruments), equipped with a TCD detector. About 100mg of the sample was placed in a U shaped quartz reactor and was pretreated at 150°C overnight under Ar (15cc/min). TPR was carried out by passing 10% H2 in Ar at a flow rate of 15cc/min through the sample. The sample was heated up to 900°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. TCD signal was used to determine the reduction temperature and the H2 consumption during reduction of the catalysts. Temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) of the spent catalyst was carried out in a similar fashion as described above for the TPR experiment. The sample was pretreated under He (15cc/min) before the TPO experiment as well. However, for TPO, the gas mixture used was 5% O2 in He, passing over the catalyst at a flow rate of 15cc/min during the experiment. 2.7 Adsorption isotherm The isotherms were determined by measuring the decrease in concentration of the adsorbate (visbroken residue) dissolved in toluene after being in contact with the mesoporous–macroporous catalyst. The adsorption experiment was carried out as follows: 10mL of toluene solutions of different concentrations of the visbroken residue were transferred to a cylindrical screw-cap glass vial. The adsorbent (1g of prepared catalyst) was placed in each vial, capped, and secured externally with paraffin film. Solution/adsorbent ratio of 10:1 (cc/g) was selected in order to ensure total overload of available adsorption sites of the adsorbent/catalyst. The vials were then gently shaken for about 48h, and the solution was left to settle for a week before measuring the uptake using UV–vis. For further details of the experiment, please refer to our previous work [15]. 2.8 Fixed bed reactor set-up The construction of a setup capable of performing both adsorption and catalytic steam gasification in a continuous operation was carried out and is described below. The bench top plant was built with the capacity of handling light as well as heavy hydrocarbon feeds. A schematic representation of the designed plant is shown in Fig. 1 . The plant consisted of a 40cm long and 1.9 (3.4 in.) cm diameter piton-type reactor and three reservoirs. The first reservoir had the feed (n-C5-asphaltenes+LCO), the second reservoir contained water, and the third contained toluene or VGO. All reservoirs were pressurized with N2. The system utilized three pumps. For toluene and water reservoirs, the pumps used were reciprocating pumps from ELDEX (model 1L MP). For the feed, the pump used was an ISCO 500D screw-type pump. Two Swagelok back pressure regulators (0–500psi) were employed to maintain the pressure during the two different modalities, adsorption and gasification experiments. A cold trap was installed (using a refrigerating and recirculating bath (LAUDA WK 300)) for the condensation of water and heavy hydrocarbon prior to the gas flow meter (model FMA-4000). The on-line gas chromatographic analysis was performed with a SRI 86106 analyzer. Omega K type thermocouples were used to keep track of process key temperatures. The thermocouples had a special configuration for the reactor, consisting of a custom 1/16 in. (0.16cm) profile probe with five reading points; each point 5cm apart. All readings were obtained with an OMEGA10 zone thermocouple scanner (model MDSSi8). The heating of the system was achieved using OMEGA heating tapes, along with K type wall thermocouples, all connected and controlled by two OMEGA PID (Proportional-Integral-Derivative) temperature controllers (model C6N16 TIC). The steam generation chamber consisted of a 1/4 in. (0.64cm) Swagelok tubing of approximately 30cm length, filled with rasching rings to improve the heat distribution, and heated with the elements previously mentioned. All connections were completed with Swagelok stainless steel tubing (1/4 in. & 1/8 in.). The ball and needle valves utilized as well as the pressure gauges of different ranges used all along the system were also from Swagelok. The reactor was made of a stainless steel tube, with an outer diameter (OD) of 3/4 in., the internal diameter (ID) of 0.62 in. or ∼1.57cm and a height of 27.67cm for 30g of catalyst. In addition 5cm both on top and bottom of the reactor were filled with an inert material (carborundum), in order to have a better distribution of flow and to heat only the middle section of the tube, to ensure having a better temperature profile. 2.9 Brief operational procedures For a better understanding on how the adsorption and gasification experiments were carried out, a brief description of the procedure is presented below. The procedure is divided into three main steps, (i) adsorption; (ii) cleaning; and (iii) gasification described in detail as follows: (i) Adsorption experiment: The reactor was filled with the catalyst (∼30g) in extrudate form. The feed was then heated to 130°C and pumped. The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) used was 2h−1 for the adsorption process. The feed continued flowing through the reactor column in the up-flow mode to adsorb asphaltenes from the feed onto the extrudate at a temperature of 250°C. Oil samples were collected at fixed time intervals at the outlet of the liquid backpressure value. The zero time for asphaltenes breakthrough was considered the moment the first droplet of liquid appeared from the reactor. (ii) Cleaning: When the adsorption process reached saturation (which was already known to be around two column volumes), the pumping of oil was stopped and the remaining heavy hydrocarbon in the porous medium was taken out of the system with the aid of VGO and then steam to complete dissolving/cleaning whatever may be left inside the porous media. (iii) Gasification: Catalytic steam gasification step started immediately after cleaning. Steam was generated, and flushed through the reactor, exiting through the gas backpressure valve. Steam gasification was carried out at 100psi. The catalyst was not reduced before gasification. Gasification experiment was carried out at one temperature before moving to the next higher temperature. It was one continuous experiment. The system temperature was increased gradually until it reached reaction temperatures of 530°C and beyond. As mentioned earlier, steam gasification of the same adsorbed material was carried out at different temperatures in succession. Liquid hydrocarbons and water were periodically drained from the cold trap separator. Gas analysis was performed every 30min with an online GC, when the system was at the specified reaction temperature. The rate of liquid water injected during the gasification was 0.2cm3/min. These conditions were maintained in the subsequent experiments. 2.10 Gas chromatography (GC) analysis Gas chromatography analyses were performed online using an SRI multiple gas analyzer model 8610#3, 120V TCD & HID detectors, and an assemble of 3′ molecular sieve/6′ Hayesep-D columns. The GC was previously calibrated with a hydrocarbon mixture gas and it took 30min for each analysis. 2.11 Nitrogen physisorption experiments Surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution for the synthesized adsorbents/catalysts were determined by N2 physisorption at 77K, using a Micromeritics Tristar 3020 equipment. Before N2 physisorption experiments, the samples were dried at 150°C overnight under N2 flow. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method was used to determine the surface areas. Surface areas obtained for the adsorbents/catalyst typically ranged between 11 and 16m2/g. 3 Results and Discussions 3.1 Thermogravimetric analysis Thermogravimetric (TG-DTA) analysis of one of the catalysts tested (3NiO6K6Ba) is presented as follows. Fig. 2 shows the TG-DTA data of extrudates before they were calcined at 650°C for 8h. For clarity, the data is presented both in temperature (Fig. 2a) and time (Fig. 2b) scale. The temperature was first raised to 80°C and held for 15min. The temperature was then raised to 120°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min and held there for 180min. A small endotherm during this temperature rise shows loss of moisture from the catalyst (Fig. 2b). The weight and heat profiles show that further loss of H2O started around 175°C. Fig. 2a shows that sugar decomposition with oxidation starts around 200°C. The carbonaceous species formed, because of combustion of sugar, oxidize after 300°C in three stages. Small mass loss (better seen in Fig. 2b) above 500°C is the decomposition of carbonates into oxides, very important for asphaltenes adsorption, as discussed in our previous work [17]. Fig. 3 shows the TG-DTA data of extrudates after they were calcined at 650°C for 8h. We can clearly see that there is no exothermic peak (showing combustion) present around 900°C showing absence of any residual carbon present in the calcined catalyst. And XRD data would show (Section 3.2) that NiO is present even after calcination and there is no transformation to another crystalline phase. Fig. 4 shows the TG-DTA data of spent 3NiO6K6Ba catalyst. Coke formed oxides around 550°C. It appears that all types of coke present on the catalyst surface combusted at one temperature probably due to the presence of excess air flowing at 100cc/min over few mg of catalyst taken for analysis. 3.2 X-ray powder diffraction Fig. 5 shows the X-ray diffraction powder pattern of the kaolin (used in catalyst preparation) before (a) and after (b) calcination at 650°C. As seen in figure, the kaolin used has some small traces of a crystalline material identified with the PDF# 00-046-0741 (potassium aluminum silicate mineral) which seems to be stable to any of the applied thermal treatments. Fig. 6 shows the XRD pattern of the NiO (as received) used in catalyst preparation (Fig. 6a), the fresh prepared catalyst (Fig. 6b) and the spent catalyst after adsorption and steam gasification (Fig. 6c). As observed in Fig. 6a, the NiO, used in synthesis, presents a broad pattern indicating very small crystalline domain sizes of NiO (PDF# 01-075-0269) and the estimated value is 7±1nm. After incorporation of NiO into the kaolin matrix and further thermal treatment at 650°C, the only two detected crystalline phases are the potassium aluminum silicate (impurity present in the original kaolin) and the added NiO (Fig. 6b), however, there is an increase in the crystalline domain sizes of the NiO going from 7±1 to 22±2nm. This last result indicates sintering of the original particles having an average diameter of about three times the original size. After reaction, the potassium aluminum silicate impurity is still present, however, the NiO is no longer observed; instead, a crystalline nickel sulfide was formed. Identification of the crystalline nickel sulfide phase indicates the formation of Ni3S2 (a synthetic counterpart of the mineral Heazlewoodite (PDF# 01-085-1802)). This nickel sulfide has Ni–Ni bond distances that resembles those of the metallic nickel [19,20] and it has been shown to possess metallic like properties [21–24]. Recently, Ni3S2 has been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions [25,26] starting from foam nickel and an aqueous soluble S-compound with temperatures around 150–200°C. The experimental conditions employed in our work with NiO-based catalyst, i.e. presence of sulphur-compounds, nano particles of NiO, temperature, and steam facilitated the formation of the Ni3S2. This should explain the catalytic behaviour as this material has metal like properties similar to metallic nickel. 3.3 Textural properties of the prepared catalysts The textural properties of our catalysts, including BET surface area and pore volume, are presented in Table 3 . Since the main target of this investigation is to selectively capture and retain heavy and unstable organic molecules present in the feed for steam gasification, it is critical to have accurate knowledge of the textural properties of the catalysts produced. Pore size distribution, measured by N2 physisorption, of the catalysts prepared showed major distribution of pore size around 400–500Å (Fig. 7 ). As the total volume of the pores having very large size significantly dropped with Ba incorporation, we further decided to incorporate NiO nanoparticles in Ba-based catalysts to study the effect of NiO incorporation on textural properties. Catalysts after NiO incorporation showed a pore size distribution in the range of 300–500Å that to our understanding facilitated adsorption (Fig. 7). Our results also showed that change of alkali metal from K to Cs in the catalyst did not affect the pore size distribution (Fig. 7). We also studied the effect of large (80g) and small scale (15–20g) catalyst preparation procedure, on the surface areas and pore size distributions. 3NiO6Cs6Ba and 3NiO6K6Ba catalysts were chosen for this purpose. It was interesting to find that the textural properties of the catalysts did not change significantly when prepared in large amounts (Fig. 8 ). This showed that the porosity was mainly controlled by the amount of sugar used as a porogen in our catalyst preparation. In order to compare differences in adsorption behaviour between catalysts prepared on small and large scale, another set of adsorption experiments involving solution of visbroken residue in toluene were carried out as mentioned before. The resulting isotherms are shown in Fig. 9 . As we can see in Fig. 9, both isotherms adjust well to a Langmuir type isotherm (using a linearization of the Langmuir equation); both catalysts seem to adsorb similarly, showing that catalysts prepared under small and large scale were having similar adsorption properties. This experiment demonstrated clearly that in our catalysts, the pore size has a larger role to play than the pore volume. The size of asphaltenes is big. Since there is no significant change in the pore size, we do not see any significant change in the adsorption capacity. 3.4 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) The TPR profiles of the Ni-based catalysts are shown in Fig. 10 . The TPR data shows that there are three reduction peaks (i.e. 400, 540 and 685°C) observed for Ni in presence of K. This shows that there are three kinds of reducible species present; an outcome of different metal-support interactions. The XRD analysis indicated that the original crystalline domain size of NiO was 7nm. However, after the calcination, the value increased almost by three times. This indicates sintering of original particle and a possibility that some atoms e.g. Ba can be incorporated into the NiO structure modifying the reduction profile as seen in TPR. Nevertheless, the amount of this solid solution is too low to be detected in XRD. However, Ni when present in combination with Cs, TPR profile shows that the reduction peak present at 540°C shifts to a lower temperature (∼500°C); thus, enabling the catalyst to reduce at a lower temperature. H2 uptake of catalysts 3Ni6Cs6Ba20S and 3Ni6K6Ba20S were 331 and 317μmol of H2/g catalyst. Typically, NiO would be reduced by H2 as shown below: NiO+H2 =Ni+H2O 3wt.% NiO when present means that we have 2.36wt.% of Ni. So from stoichiometric point of view, this translates into consumption of 402μmol of H2 per g of catalyst. Our experimental values obtained for H2 consumption shows that almost 80% of the metal is able to get reduced up to 900°C. 3.5 Temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) Temperature programmed oxidation of the spent catalyst was carried out as described in Section 2. The TPO profile obtained is shown in Fig. 11 . The profile clearly showed the presence of two kinds of carbon on the catalytic surface. The amount of CO2 produced was determined to be 2935μmol/g of catalyst. This translated into 35mg of carbon/g of the catalyst (3.5wt.%). 3.6 Catalytic steam gasification of n-C5-asphaltenes onto different catalysts All four catalysts were tested using a stream consisting of n-C5 industrial asphaltenes dissolved in LCO for catalytic steam gasification and compared. The temperatures used for catalytic steam gasification tests ranged from 560 to 730°C, as this temperature range has been studied previously [11,27,28]. The average CSG gas composition obtained for 6K6Ca catalyst is shown in Table 4 . We can observe from the data given in the table that the changes in gas composition has a clear trend. H2 and CO concentration decreased, while CO2 concentration increased with increase in reaction temperature. A plausible explanation to the trend observed is that at higher temperatures CSG reactions are favoured, therefore, more H2 (and less CO) is produced. Also the abundance of H2 then seems to favour CH4 producing reactions, as we see an increase in CH4 amount. The proposed set of reactions occurring are shown in Table 5 . The H2/CO2 ratio decreased with increase in the reaction temperature, which is indicative of CSG as it gets closer to the value of 2, according to the global CSG reaction (Eq. (1), comprising the water gas reaction and the water gas shift reaction). (1) C + 2 H 2 O → 2 H 2 + C O 2 It should be kept in mind that the hydrocarbons adsorbed and some present in the reactor also have hydrogen, so the ratio will be in most cases slightly higher than 2. Fig. 12 shows, as expected, higher temperature leads to higher gas flow rates. For a better understanding of the data, the results obtained for the remaining three catalysts, along with 6K6Ca catalyst discussed above, are presented together for a quick comparison in Figs. 13 and 14. In Fig. 13 , it can be observed that the trend in product formation discussed during CSG over 6K6Ca catalyst are repeated with subtle differences for the rest of the catalysts tested. H2 and CO amounts are decreasing while CH4 and CO2 amounts are increasing with increase in the reaction temperature. Fig. 14 shows a plot of the average gas rates divided by the catalyst metals content at different reaction temperatures. An increase in H2, CH4 and CO2 rates with increasing the reaction temperature is evident, while CO rate seems to remain almost unchanged. The mass balance for all CSG experiments closed with a value very close to 100%. A comparison of Fig. 13a and b will show the effect of Ba incorporation into the catalyst. We can observe certain differences in CSG by 6K6Ca and 6K6Ba catalysts. H2 percentage is slightly higher for the catalyst containing Ba, and the CO content decreases at a higher rate and reaches low vales (<5%) at temperatures as low as 650°C (Fig. 13). It is most likely the bigger size of the alkali ion that plays a role in increasing H2 production. For 6K6Ba catalyst, CH4 and CO2 produced appear to reach a plateau, whereas for 6K6Ca catalyst it follows the trend described previously; however reaching similar values at higher temperatures. A comparison of catalytic steam gasification by 6K6Ba and 3NiO6K6Ba (Fig. 13b and c) shows that the addition of Ni seems to have significant effect. First, we see a reduction in CO percentage, which goes to levels close to zero. CH4 percentage also drops to roughly half of that obtained for 6K6Ba catalyst. H2 content is higher, with percentages higher than 60%. This demonstrates spill over effect of H2 by Ni [29,30]. CO2 percentage also increases for the catalyst containing Ni. These behaviours seem to indicate more shift towards water–gas shift reaction, producing more H2, CO2, and less CO. Also CH4 producing reactions seem to have been reduced, perhaps from the fact that less CO is available. Also, XRD data showed that Ni exists as Ni3S2 in the spent catalyst and not as a metallic Ni (which is well known to be a methanation catalyst), therefore, a decrease in CH4 production perhaps becomes a possibility. However, as already discussed in Section 3.2, there are reports that Ni3S2 may behave as metallic Ni in some cases; a rationale we suggest to explain the increased H2 production. Comparing 3NiO6K6Ba with 3NiO6Cs6Ba catalyst for CSG (Fig. 13c, d), we can observe less H2 for the Cs containing catalyst, as well as higher CO percentages. CH4 and CO2 values are not that apart from each other. What seems to be happening is again related to water gas shift reaction, where K containing catalyst seems to be favouring this reaction more than the Cs containing catalyst. It can also be noted that the CH4 percentages decrease with the addition of Ni to the catalyst, an indication that methanation is reduced. A plausible explanation can be that less CO available for methanation is present in the gases. We can also observe that the catalyst 3NiO6Cs6Ba produce the highest amount of gases, followed by 6K6Ba, 3NiO6K6Ba and 6K6Ca. More information about the gas production is presented in Fig. 14. In Fig. 14, we can see we have similar trends for H2, CH4, and CO2 production. Rates for these products increase with an increase in temperature. However, CO trends are not similar. CO flow rates are really low for 3NiO6K6Ba (Fig. 14), which is expected since the composition of CO obtained was close to zero. For 3NiO6Cs6Ba and 6K6Ca, CO slightly increased, and seems to reach a sort of plateau around 20% for both catalysts. For 6K6Ba, we have a decreasing trend, and that is due to the fact that the CO composition decreased abruptly with temperature for this catalyst, as shown in Fig. 13. Ni containing catalysts seem to be more active, producing more H2 per mol of metal in the catalyst matrix. Between these two that contain Ni, Cs containing catalyst seems to be the most active, producing slightly more H2 per mol compared to the one containing K (3NiO6K6Ba). This is in contrast to previous observations where the activity for gasification increased with decrease in ionic size of the metal [10]. We have seen previously [17] that the basicity did not vary much when Ca was replaced by Ba in the catalyst support. Probably, it is the size of the alkali ion that plays the major role in increasing H2 production rather than the global basicity. TPR profile shown in Fig. 10 also suggest that Ni when present with Cs gets reduced at a lower temperature than when present with K. Between the catalysts that do not have Ni, 6K6Ca seems to be more active than 6K6Ba. A plausible explanation is the eutectic effects created by K–Ca mixture [10]. Considering the main gasification reaction, C+2H2O=2H2 +CO2, as a zero order reaction and the rate constant k =[H2]/2, a plot of lnk vs 1/T gave the activation energies for each catalytic reaction. A comparison of activation energies, gas rate and H2/CO2 ratio (at 650°C) can be seen in Table 6 and Figs. 15 and 16 . Fig. 15 shows that the gas rate is highest for 3NiO6Cs6Ba, while the lowest was obtained for 6K6Ba. Also, we can observe that the addition of Ni seems to improve the process, lowering the activation energy (Fig. 16), as well as increasing the gas rate (Fig. 15). Between the two nickel-based catalysts, 3NiO6Cs6Ba seems to be the more promising material, with slightly lower activation energy, and the higher production of gases per moles of metal contained in the catalyst. Surprisingly, the lowest activation energy value was obtained for 6K6Ca. We believe that KCa catalyst has the lowest activation energy mainly because of the reason the KCa binary oxide mixture remains most molten during gasification process. In addition to a more abundant contact when a liquid phase ‘wets’ the carbon to be gasified, in binary oxides at eutectic point (melted), the mobility and lability of O radicals have considerably increased at the surface of the melted catalyst. This helps to increase the overall carbon conversion rate, thus, lowering the activation energy. However, H2/CO2 ratio was highest for 6K6Ca among all catalysts tested. For Ni based catalysts, the value was almost 2, indicating less side reactions for Ni containing catalysts and therefore a better steam gasification catalysts. 4 Conclusions This study demonstrated the possibility of low temperature catalytic steam gasification of adsorbed asphaltenes in a fixed bed reactor unit. The effect of incorporating alkali, alkaline earth and transition metal on catalytic activity for steam gasification was studied in detail. Replacement of Ca by Ba increased H2 production. However, incorporation of NiO nanoparticles promoted further H2 production during the steam gasification of the adsorbed asphaltenes, leading to CO2 and H2 as major products with less side reactions. coredata.dc:description: A possibility of low temperature catalytic steam gasification of n-C5 asphaltenes mixed in light cyclic oil (LCO) in a fixed bed reactor is tested and presented. Four meta kaolin based catalysts containing one alkali (K or Cs), one alkaline earth (Ca or Ba) metal oxides were characterized and tested. Two of these four catalysts also contained NiO nanoparticles in addition to alkali and alkaline earth metal oxides. Addition of sugar as a porogen to kaolin created meso as well as macroporosity. These mesoporous–macroporous meta kaolin based materials are intended to work mainly as catalysts for steam gasification of the adsorbed asphaltenes. XRD data showed presence of Ni3S2 in the spent catalyst. It was found that low temperature catalytic steam gasification was possible by all four catalysts. However, replacement of Ca by Ba increased H2 production. Also, incorporation of NiO nanoparticles promoted further H2 production during the steam gasification of the adsorbed asphaltenes, leading to CO2 and H2 as major products with less side reactions. Of the two nickel-based catalysts, 3NiO6Cs6Ba seems to be the more promising material, with slightly lower activation energy, and higher production of gases per mole of metal contained in the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic steam gasification of n-C5 asphaltenes by kaolin-based catalysts in a fixed-bed reactor
